document.author: Kathy Quiano, CNN
document.title: Will Indonesia lose right to directly elect governors?

highlights.sentence: Indonesia&apost;s parliament will vote on a bill to strip the right to directly elect local leaders.
Critics say it is a retrograde move; backers say democracy has become too expensive.
The move is being backed by the coalition that backed the losing presidential candidate.
They could pass the bill into law before President-elect Joko Widodo takes office.

sentence.content: Indonesia&apost;s parliament is set to vote Thursday on a revised election bill that will take away voters&apost; rights to directly elect local leaders, in what critics say it is a huge step backward for the country&apost;s fledgling democracy.
Proponents of the bill, which would scrap direct elections for mayors and governors, say local elections have proven too costly, and are prone to conflict and corruption.
The bill is being backed by the coalition behind losing presidential candidate Prabowo Subianto.
"Democracy has become too expensive," Fadli Zon, vice chairman of Subianto&apost;s Gerindra party, recently told a forum of journalists.
Zon estimates the government will save about 60 trillion rupiah or $5 billion, if direct regional elections are eliminated.
"If the regional election is done by the regional house of representatives, it is estimated that the expenditure needed would only be the cost for tea and coffee," he argued.
Bad move?
Critics disagree, and question the timing of the push to pass the bill, first proposed in 2012, just two months after the election of president-elect Joko Widodo.
Six of nine political parties support the revisions and most are part of the coalition that backed Subianto.
"I think it&apost;s unseemly," said Sarwono Kusumaatmadja, a former minister under former president Suharto, and now senior government affairs adviser at Transformasi, a Jakarta-based think tank.
"It won&apost;t change the nature of politics, it won&apost;t make politics any cleaner.
It will only shift the money politics somewhere else, to the oligarchs, and the victims are the Indonesian people," he added.
"Just when they were just enjoying their rights and seeing some good people rise, based on a constituency based politics, they see the game being taken away from them."
Widodo&apost;s rise.
Widodo was swept into power through the popular vote.
He was first elected as mayor of Solo in Central Java in 2005 and then as governor of the nation&apost;s capital Jakarta in 2012.

"Direct elections are important because it is the fruit of the 32 years of Indonesia&apost;s struggle for democracy," student leader Mohamad Ivan Riansa told a small protest in front of the parliament building Wednesday.
Under former dictator Suharto&apost;s 32-year rule, local leaders were chosen by political parties that won seats in local assemblies.
After the fall of his regime in 1998, Indonesia launched a rapid process of political and electoral reform, involving a decentralization of power from the national government.
In 2004, Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono became the first directly-elected president of Indonesia.
A year later, voters were given the right to choose their own local leaders for the very first time.
The massive democratic undertaking required elections to be staggered over five years throughout the country&apost;s 34 provinces and 511 districts or municipalities.
Direct elections favored.
A recent opinion survey by the Indonesian Survey Circle showed that 81% of Indonesians prefer direct local elections.
Choosing local leaders was a relatively new and confusing experience for some Indonesians, taxi driver Nana Suryana told CNN.
"It&apost;s better for the local assembly to choose the candidates because they know better than we do.
People might choose the wrong one," he said.
While voter turnout had been declining since 2009, a new wave of politicians, including Widodo, energized a largely apathetic electorate this year, particularly young voters.
"Most of us abstained from voting before the presidential 2014 elections," musician Viddy Supit told CNN.
"We&apost;re now aware that we have to use our voices to develop our nation.
That&apost;s why we&apost;re here to support direct regional elections."

Titi Anggraini, director of the Association for Elections and Democracy (Perludem), said that holding simultaneous elections, to decrease costs, and focusing on voter education would be more effective steps to strengthen Indonesia&apost;s democracy.
"If this bill is passed, it&apost;s not only dangerous, but it is stealing our rights, our constitutional rights," Anggraini said.
SBY veto?
Outgoing President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, whose Democrat Party supports the bill, has said he supports direct elections.
The President can veto the bill before his term ends and Widodo takes over on October 20.
Anggraini said his group had appealed to Yudhoyono in an open letter.

"Pak Presiden SBY (Mr. President SBY), you are the person who gained the most from democracy, from reformasi (reform), so at the end of your term, please give us the sweet fruits of democracy", said Anggraini.
Current parliamentarians are set to vote on the revised bill Thursday, just days before their terms end on September 30.
